Explanation: What is it called?
What is X's name?
Literally means "cannot be known".

Explanation: Used at the end of a sentence to provide emphasis when giving information. Use "yo" for male and "da yo"/"wa yo"  for female colloquial speech.
Rules: X yo / X n da yo / X wa yo @ X = verb
X yo / X da yo / X wa yo @ X = noun/na-adj./i-adj.
X ka @ X = verb
Raise tone and omit "ka" when question is in plain form.
kai or "kae" also used in familiar language.

Explanation: Used similarly to the interrogative "ka" after a verb, "ka naa" is used by males and "ka shira" by females.
Rules: X ka naa/ka shira

Explanation: no is sometimes used to stress the uncertaintyl/doubt.

X na no ka naa/ka shira @ X = noun, na-adj.

Use "X ni … wo …" construction when the verb originally uses the "wo" marker, e.g. "wo taberu".
Use "X wo … ni …" construction when the verb requires the use of the "ni" marker, e.g. "ni iku".

Explanation: Used to emphasize a fact or action.

Explanation: Used to emphasize a fact or action. Use "doori" when juxtaposing "toori" to a noun to create a compund noun.

Explanation: Used to emphasize an action or state of being.
